data: Funerary inscription for Leontia and Kalliope
Triangular marble plaque. In the lower corners are two menorah and a conic figure, perhaps an ethrog.
Original discovery not recorded; probably from Catania (according to Ferrara and Noy), but possibly from the Monteverde catacomb in Rome (according to Ferrua and Korhonen).
Observed by Torremuzza and Kaibel in Museo Biscari, later by Korhonen in magazzino superiore, collezione Biscari (formerly sala VII, 85)

Facsimile Images

Apparatus criticus

Text based on photographs; Torremuzza and Franz observed only the first epitaph, without the indication of the age; 9: The second menorah is followed by an ethrog (or a shofar according to Ferrara)

English translation

Jonathan Prag

Here lies Leontia, aged 3. Here lies Kalliope, aged 18.

Italian translation

Serena Agodi

Qui giace Leontia di anni 3. Qui giace Calliope di anni 18.

commentary

These two Jewish epitaphs may not come from Catania: in describing the Biscari collection, Ferrara gives an imprecise indication of the provenance of this inscription and the structure á¼”Î½Î¸Î±Î´Îµ ÎºÎµá¿–Ï„Î±Î¹ á½ Î´Îµá¿–Î½Î± á¼Ï„á¿¶Î½ is rather typical of the inscriptions from the Monteverde catacombs and not attested elsewhere in Catania. On the provenance, see the discussion in Korhonen 2001: 90-93. In any case, a Jewish community is well attested in Catania, as IMusCatania 228 = ISic000781 of the 4th cent. CE confirms. The two girls were probably related (perhaps sisters). Both names are attested in the Jewish environment: both Leontia, probably a Jewish translation of Judith attested in CIJ 369 (Rome), and Kalliope, attested in BS II 136, 137, 200 (Beth Sheâ€™arim, see also the Christian inscriptions of Syracuse IGCVO 948, 1321), however, are also popular among non-Jews (on both names, see Rutgers 1997: 249-250).

Italy Sicily Catania Museo Civico di Catania 541 Ancient Greek

Triangular marble plaque. In the lower corners are two menorah and a conic figure, perhaps an ethrog.

marble plaque 19.5 29.5 2 chiselled Letters with serifs: Î‘, Î”, Î› with extended serifs, Î‘ with broken bar, lunate Î•, cursive Î©. The supraline indicates the abbreviation of Î½. In the lower corner of the stone are two menorah and a conical figure, perhaps an ethrog (a type of citron, used in the festival of Sukkot) or an amphora. According to Ferrare, the symbol can represent a shofar (a small ram's-horn trumpet). Kaibel did not understand this symbol, interpreting it as part of a Î¥.

Lines 1-9 11-21 Interlineation line 1 to 2 not recorded Catina Catania 37.49223, 15.07041 Probably 4th century CE. Original discovery not recorded; probably from Catania (according to Ferrara and Noy), but possibly from the Monteverde catacomb in Rome (according to Ferrua and Korhonen). Observed by Torremuzza and Kaibel in Museo Biscari, later by Korhonen in magazzino superiore, collezione Biscari (formerly sala VII, 85) Display, Voci di pietra no.35
